So I'm not even sure where to start with this. Work has been absolute chaos the last few weeks. My boss pulled me into a meeting Monday and basically said the whole department might be restructured by end of Q1. No timeline, no details, just "we're evaluating options." I've been there eleven years and that's the kind of thing that makes your stomach drop, you know?

I've been telling myself it's probably fine. Companies do this all the time and people stay. But honestly I can't stop running worst case scenarios in my head. What if I'm the one they let go? I have my mortgage, my car payment, and my mom's care stuff to think about. It's not just about me being upset about work, it's the logistics of it all falling apart. I've started looking at my savings like three times a day which is ridiculous but I can't seem to stop.

My partner thinks I'm catastrophizing. Maybe I am. But that doesn't make the possibility less real, does it? Anyway, I figured I should probably talk to someone about this instead of just spiraling alone at night. That's why I'm reaching out.
exchanges.assistant:
**The uncertainty of the restructuring:**

Eleven years is a long time, and being blindsided with "we're evaluating options" without any timeline or details—that's disorienting. Your stomach dropping makes complete sense. You've built a place where you belong, and now suddenly it's in limbo. That gap between what you know (what is) and what you're trying to figure out (what could be) is exhausting.

**The catastrophizing label:**

Your partner called it catastrophizing, and I hear that they're trying to help. But let's step back: catastrophizing usually means imagining the worst and treating it like it's already happening. You're running worst-case scenarios, but you're also clearly aware that maybe it's not you, that people do stay. That's not catastrophizing—that's your brain trying to prepare for every possibility so you're not caught off guard. The problem is, when you run every bad outcome, you don't get to rest. Every scenario needs to be evaluated.

One thing that might help: when you notice yourself spiraling into "what if I'm the one they let go?" try naming it as what it is. "I'm running a worst-case scenario right now." That creates a little distance. Then ask yourself: what's the evidence that this might happen? What's the evidence that it might not? You don't have to solve it yet—you're just noticing which thoughts are based on facts and which are based on fear.

**The savings-checking:**

Checking your savings three times a day is your brain trying to feel in control in a situation that feels completely out of your hands. The problem is, checking doesn't actually give you control—it just keeps you anxious. You're looking at the same numbers over and over, and you're not making any better decisions than the first time you looked.

What if we tried this: next time the urge hits to check your savings, instead of giving in, do something physical. Take a walk, stretch, grab coffee. Give yourself one window each day—maybe morning and evening—to actually look at your numbers. The rest of the time, the money is there, and you'll deal with it when you intentionally choose to. That's not perfect, but it's better than the current loop.

**The bigger picture:**

You said "it's not just about me being upset about work, it's the logistics of it all falling apart." That's true. Your mortgage, your car, your mom's care—those are real responsibilities, and the thought of them being harder to manage is terrifying. That fear is making sense of you. It's like, "okay, so if I can't afford these things, what happens?" and your brain jumps straight to catastrophe.

But here's the thing: right now, you're paying your mortgage, you're making your car payment, and you're taking care of your mom. Those things are working. The situation hasn't changed. What's changed is the uncertainty, and uncertainty is hard because it makes us imagine the worst. Your brain isn't broken for doing that—it's just trying to protect you.

You came here because you're spiraling alone at night, and you want to stop. That makes sense. This isn't about catastrophizing or being dramatic—it's about real fears in a real uncertain situation. We can work on that.
